title: Memory Identity Explorer
description:
Explore how Python stores variables in memory using id() function.

Create a program that:
1. Creates two variables with the same integer value (small integer like 100)
2. Checks if they have the same memory address (id)
3. Creates two lists with identical contents
4. Checks if they have the same memory address
5. Explains the difference

Expected output:
Integers: same object? True
Lists: same object? False
Reason: Small integers are cached, lists are separate objects
starterCode:
# Part 1: Integer identity
a = 100
b = 100

# TODO: Check if a and b have same id

# Part 2: List identity
list1 = [1, 2, 3]
list2 = [1, 2, 3]

# TODO: Check if list1 and list2 have same id

# TODO: Print explanation
solution:
# Part 1: Integer identity
a = 100
b = 100

# Check if a and b have same id
same_int = id(a) == id(b)
print(f"Integers: same object? {same_int}")

# Part 2: List identity
list1 = [1, 2, 3]
list2 = [1, 2, 3]

# Check if list1 and list2 have same id
same_list = id(list1) == id(list2)
print(f"Lists: same object? {same_list}")

# Print explanation
print("Reason: Small integers are cached, lists are separate objects")
hints: Use id(variable) to get memory address
Small integers (-5 to 256) are cached by Python
Lists are always separate objects even with identical values
Use the exact output format shown

testCases.description: Should show lists have different identity

testCases.expectedOutput: Reason: Small integers are cached, lists are separate objects
